Award.AwardTitle: Clausal Ellipsis, Its Structure and Online Processing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to investigate the structure of ellipsis from the point of view of theoretical syntax and online sentence processing. Specifically, the project emphasizes the view that a detailed study in the theoretical syntax of ellipsis provides invaluable insight into the mechanism of the structure building process in online sentence processing. The particular type of ellipsis that will be examined in this project is known as 'sluicing' (e.g., "John said Mary was reading in the garden, but he didn't say what").

Previous studies of ellipsis have used sluicing as an argument against the position that the grammar supports the unpronounced abstract syntactic structure. (e.g., because sluicing does not always respect syntactic island constraints). Dr. Yoshida will investigate whether ellipsis sites in sluicing are associated with a full-fledged syntactic structure and, if so, what the syntactic properties of those sites are. In addition, the experimental studies of how sluicing constructions are processed on line will investigate: (i) When the parser identifies the ellipsis; (ii) What representation the parser builds in the ellipsis site during online processing; and (iii) What constraint the online structure building process obeys.

In addition to advancing our understanding of the syntax of natural language and how humans identify and process the structure of sentences in the course of language comprehension, this project will also provide valuable training opportunities for graduate students in linguistics and psycholinguistics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For most people, a sentence is a list of words. However, research has found that a sentence has abstract structures and that words are combined into sentences according to those structures. While each word is meaningful on its own, the cognitive process that combines words into sentences is not typically accessible to conscious examination. Revealing this unconscious process involves a particular experimental methodology. The goal of this project is to uncover the nature of the unconscious structure of sentences and how they are used when reading sentences, making use of this experimental methodology. To achieve this, the project has examined the structure and understanding of word omission and long-distance dependency constructions. These constructions have long been known to be problematic for existing syntactic and sentence processing theories.

            A compelling example of unconscious knowledge of abstract linguistic structure is ellipsis, a construction involving omission. For example, in a sentence like "John ate something, but I don’t know what," the words after the wh-word, "what," are omitted. Even though no word is present, native speakers clearly understand that this sentence has the exact same meaning as "John ate something, but I don’t know what he ate." Native speakers can infer the omitted portion of the sentence effortlessly. How is this possible? There has been a long-standing debate about how they are able to arrive at the meaning of the ellipsis. Traditionally, it has been argued that the elided portion has the same structure as the non-ellipsis construction, the only difference being that this mentally constructed structure is not pronounced. Because the ellipsis site is associated with grammatical structure, the specific interpretation of the ellipsis site is possible.

            One predominant view, however, strongly argues against such a structural view of ellipsis. Under these analyses, the ellipsis site is not associated with grammatical structures. Rather, in this view, native speakers can infer the interpretation of ellipsis when they are given proper contexts in which these sentences are used, without recourse to grammatical structure. If these researchers are correct, we do not expect to find any structural effects inside the ellipsis site.

            Through various experiments, this project shows that an ellipsis construction does indeed have the same structure as that of non-omission sentences. In other words, the ellipsis site has invisible grammatical structure that English speakers use immediately and automatically. The main finding in this project is that sentences that involve the omission show basically the same properties as non-omission sentences. In an environment where regular non-ellipsis wh-questions are ungrammatical, ellipsis wh-questions are also ungrammatical. To demonstrate this, detailed grammatical and experimental studies of ellipsis constructions have been conducted.
